subcats.problem: Digital shadows are made up of the information websites collect about us every time we go online. Other people can use those details maliciously. Doxing is when our private information, such as phone number or address, is made public online in order to harass us.
subcats.solution:
Find out what your digital shadow looks like so you know what can be used against you. To do this, try self-doxing; use a search engine like DuckDuckGo, which protects your privacy, to search for details like your usernames, phone number and email addresses.
Tap here to search for your digital shadow.
subcats.tips:
Self-dox regularly. Knowing what your digital shadow looks like can help you to make better decisions about the information you put online.
Search for all information that could be used to identify or trace you, including:
  • all your usernames on active profiles as well as inactive/past online profiles
  • all email addresses to see where your email has been posted or possibly misused
  • your phone number(s) including landlines and mobile phones
  • your home and family addresses
Do a reverse image lookup, using a tool like Google Image Search or TinEye, on your public pictures, such as Facebook profile photos to see if they have been used anywhere else.

subcats.problem: Our browsers can give a lot of information away. Websites placing small ‘cookie’ tracking files on our computers, Facebook ‘like’ clicks on a news site and browsing histories - all can be easily accessed by whoever has access to our browsers, whether our devices are shared, lost, stolen or hacked.
subcats.solution:
In a few simple steps you can easily protect your browser and online interactions from prying eyes.
  • Look for “https” in the address bar of websites - without it, whatever you are typing can be seen by other people
  • Log out of your online accounts - even if you have a password to lock your device
  • Browse in “private mode” to stop your browser keeping a record of the websites you visit
  • Try to stop websites tracking you by enabling ‘do not track’ - be aware that some websites will ignore this though
  • Clear your cookies, other temporary internet files and browser history regularly - bookmark pages if you need to come back to them, never download your history
subcats.tips:
Public WiFi can be helpful, but it is also an easy way for hackers to gain access to your computer. Before connecting, remember to turn on your computer’s firewall and turn off any sharing options to protect your computer against any unwanted access.
There are add-ons which can help with securing your browser and internet activities:
  • HTTPS Everywhere ensures that you are always connected securely to websites through “https”, which keeps your information private
  • Privacy Badger helps to protect you from trackers that contribute to your digital shadow
  • NoScript is a Firefox extension that helps protect you from security problems by stopping websites from running small programs without your permission
